race.name: Black Forest Gravel
race.tagline: German Black Forest mountainous gravel in Freiburg.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Black Forest. Significant elevation with forest scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional German event. Mountainous Black Forest terrain with moderate organization and regional field.

biased_opinion.summary: Black Forest Gravel is a regional event in Freiburg, Germany—mountainous terrain with significant elevation. The Black Forest scenery is nice, but the moderate organization and regional field keep it firmly in Tier 3.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid regional German gravel race with Black Forest mountains. Worth it for German/European cyclists. Not a destination race for international travelers.

final_verdict.one_liner: German Black Forest mountainous gravel in Freiburg.
final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're in Germany/Europe—yes, it's solid. If you're international—there are better options.
final_verdict.alternatives: For similar German events: King of the Lake.

logistics.food: Freiburg has full dining options. Stock nutrition.
logistics.camping: Camping directly at festival grounds, described as "echte Festival-Atmosphäre" (real festival atmosphere) (https://gravel-rallye

non_negotiables.why: Black Forest mountains require sustained effort.

marketplace_variables.race_hook: German Black Forest mountainous gravel in Freiburg.

logistics.explanation: Freiburg location offers solid transportation infrastructure and tourism support, though specific race-day logistics remain unclear. Registration opens December 1st with incentives like jersey draws and beer caps, suggesting organizers are building systems but details on parking and packet pickup aren't yet specified.

length.explanation: 65 miles hits the gravel sweet spot - long enough to hurt, short enough to survive poor pacing decisions. Pete Hitzeman describes the distance as delivering "leg-shattering, lung-busting climbing" while still being manageable for exploring Black Forest terrain without needing headlamps. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar.

technicality.explanation: No surface breakdown or technical difficulty details available in research. Black Forest terrain suggests some challenges, but without course specifics or rider reports, this scores on potential rather than proven technical demands. Could be fire roads, could be singletrack - roll the dice. Less technical than The Mid South. As Anonymous rider puts it: "The Black Fork Gravel Grinder was a proper tough gravel race. With punchy climbs, ripping descents and some rugged sections, it was right up my alley…. 10/10 would do this event again!"

elevation.explanation: 4500 feet over 65 miles means consistent climbing through "the most beautiful peaks in the Black Forest" without Alpine suffering. The terrain delivers "punchy climbs" and "ripping descents" that keep your heart rate honest throughout the route's rolling profile. Similar elevation profile to Gravel Worlds.

climate.explanation: Historical weather data shows average highs of 75°F and lows of 56°F, with a 51% chance of rain on any given day. July timing avoids the worst of German summer heat and winter mud seasons. Black Forest region gets weather variety but nothing extreme by gravel standards, with dense forests providing natural climate moderation throughout the route. Similar climate challenges to SBT GRVL.

altitude.explanation: Black Forest elevations won't challenge your red blood cell count - this isn't Colorado suffering at high altitude. The region's moderate elevations mean sea level lungs work fine, with the focus on rolling terrain rather than oxygen-depleting climbs. Modest altitude compared to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

adventure.explanation: The Black Forest delivers backcountry mystique through "Lange Schotter Alleen" (long gravel avenues) with "no cell service" reported by riders. Routes explore remote terrain with "breathtaking views and dense forests" where wildlife encounters are common.

prestige.explanation: Third edition in 2026 means this event barely has training wheels off. No pro field or notable winners documented, and it's not mentioned alongside Unbound or SBT GRVL in gravel conversations. Olympic champion Michael Rich endorses the format, but field depth remains thin.

race_quality.explanation: Registration opens December 1st with prize draws for jerseys and beer caps - always a red flag when the pre-race swag gets more marketing than the actual course details. No aid station info, no cutoff times, no surface breakdown available. Hard to deliver quality when the basics are still TBD.

experience.explanation: The Black Forest delivers adventure through Dreisamtal with riders praising "breathtaking views of rural terrain" and wildlife encounters. One rider noted the scenery was "so breathtaking, I was beside myself" despite challenging physical demands through dense forests.

community.explanation: Event attracts "Mountain Bikers, Gravel Grinders, Cyclocross Enthusiasts, Adventure Cyclists, and Fat Bike Fanatics" with post-race festivities featuring "Lagerfeuer, Smoker BBQ, hausgemachster Flammkuchen" and vinyl music. Riders consistently praise volunteer support and grassroots organization.

field_depth.explanation: With a field of 200-400 riders, three years old with zero notable winners or pro participation documented. The prize structure revolves around gear giveaways instead of meaningful purse money. You're racing weekend warriors, not elite talent. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100. As Anonymous rider puts it: "The Black Fork Gravel Grinder was a proper tough gravel race. With punchy climbs, ripping descents and some rugged sections, it was right up my alley…. 10/10 would do this event again!"

value.explanation: €70 entry fee includes all food and drink at GenussHotSpots throughout the route, offering "Black Forest tapas, barista coffee, ice cream, and Rothaus beer." The Black Forest location delivers substantial terrain value for 65 miles and 4500 feet of climbing.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs €60-100. Freiburg means German prices for lodging and food - your wallet will feel every euro. Michael Rich recommends "wide tires for better comfort" on the technical terrain, but no specific information on parking, nearest airports, or accommodation logistics available. Higher total cost than Badlands.

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners
